data.text: Contents
Introduction
This policy is required to provide guidance for staff across the MSE theatres about the requirements and processes for all visitors to the Operating Theatres and Recovery Departments across the MSE.

Article 8 of The Human Rights Act (HMSO, 1998) states; “Everyone has the right for his private and family life, his home and correspondence, to be private unless it is in the interests of national security, public safety or the protection of others.” This highlights the importance of the issue of maintaining confidentiality and privacy for patients, and reinforces the need for patients to be informed and their consent obtained for the presence of any visitors during their care.
Purpose
The purpose of this document is to identify the process that visitors/outside contractors must follow in order to enter any operating theatre across the MSE Trust.

Safe patient care is the priority of the Operating Theatres. Patients have the right to confidentiality and have the right to refuse the presence of visitors, visiting surgeons or nurses taking part during their perioperative phase of care.

Visitors to the operating theatre are restricted to those who have a direct relevance to the delivery of a patient's care, i.e. carers, parents, company representatives supporting surgeons and translators.

Those who are attending theatres to participate in direct patient care who are not employed by the Trust will be required to have an honorary contract. If they are non NHS employees they will require Occupational Health Clearance.
Definitions

table_items.text: Any Trust member of staff not employed by the Operating Theatres Department Any member of staff undertaking training or on placement in the Trust, not directly employed by the Operating Theatres Department Relatives/visitors of patients Company representatives Any member of staff or other who is not directly involved in the surgical care of the patient Interpreters/Big Word Visiting clinical staff from other hospitals Outside Contractors

data.text: Duties
T and A Clinical Divisional Governance Committee are responsible for ensuring the actions from the findings/monitoring report are completed.
Theatres Governance and Practice Group- will receive the findings/monitoring report from Theatres.
The Managing Director and Trust Board are collectively responsible for minimising the risk to patients and staff by ensuring compliance and monitoring of this policy.
T and A Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that all medical staff comply with this policy.
MSE Matron T and A is responsible for ensuring that all staff adhere to this policy.

All staff have a responsibility for ensuring that the principles outlined within this document are universally applied. This policy applies to all members of staff who are involved in any aspect of the development and use of procedure development.
All visitors
Southend Hospital

All Hospital visitors must report to the Main Theatre Reception/Stores manager or one of his/her team in the Main Operating Theatre for Main/DSU/Minor ops clinic. (For outlying areas, visitors must report to Obstetric/Ophthalmic receptions).
Broomfield Hospital
All Hospital visitors must report to the Main Theatre Reception.
Basildon Hospital
Students report to the education office.
Across all MSE theatres
All visitors must be recorded in the Visitors Book in reception. This information must include date, name, company, location, signature, time in and time out.
5.4.1 All visitors must use the hand gel on entering and leaving the department and comply with PPE.
5.4.2 Visitors must be clearly identified wearing a visitors badge issued by the theatre Stores Management team.

5.4.3 All visitors must be made aware that all procedures within the Operating Theatres are confidential in nature and that any information, discussions, technical details or documentation data must be treated in confidence. The relevant Theatre coordinator for the area must be informed of all visitors to the department.
5.4.4 It is essential that all visitors are chaperoned at all times whilst in the operating department.
5.4.5 All visitors are the responsibility of the person that they are assigned to.
5.4.6 Visitors must be made aware of the procedure should they feel faint or unwell.
5.4.7 All company representatives must display their company badge.
5.4.8 All Visitors from other Trusts must wear their hospital identification badges at all times.
5.4.9 All visitors that enter the restricted areas of the Operating Theatres must be provided with the correct attire and have an understanding of how it must be worn.
5.4.10 The presence of a visitor/external contractor should be recorded on the theatre computer system including name and position, and company if a representative.
Patient duty of care
The patient must be informed that there will be visitors in attendance during his or her procedure, and the visitor's designation. For example:
Medical representative
6.2.1  If the patient refuses to give consent for a visitor to be present, the patient's decision must be respected. Any objection should be documented in the patient's notes/perioperative care plan.
Relatives, friends and staff accompanying patients

6.3.1 It is recommended that patients with special needs are accompanied into the perioperative environment by a support person, however, this is on a case by case assessment and in conjunction with the operating surgeon, to ensure that patients individual needs are met)This person may also be in attendance during the recovery phase of the patient's surgical journey.

6.3.2 Children may be accompanied into the anaesthetic room by a parent or carer or at least by a member of staff who is familiar to the child. The parent/carer may also be present in Recovery and considered an asset to the child's care.
6.3.3 At Basildon it is not usual to have the parent/carer in Recovery unless the child is very distressed.

6.3.4 A woman taken to maternity theatres can be accompanied to theatre by her husband/partner if she so wishes. The partner should be supported and appropriately prepared in the protocols to be observed for the perioperative phase of care.
6.3.5 Patients with language problems may be accompanied by an interpreter/Big word representative.
6.3.6 Confused patients may be accompanied by someone they know.
6.3.7 At Broomfield this is by prior arrangement and must comply with isolation/swabbing of relatives prior to admission for all elective patients.
6.3.8 Psychiatric patients may be accompanied by a registered mental health nurse.
Procedure for the attendance of company representatives

6.4.1 All suppliers must ensure that their representatives make an appointment with the member of staff they wish to visit and MIAWEB. Cold calling by representatives in Theatre will not be permitted in order to prevent disruption to hospital services.

6.4.2 All members of staff including medical staff who are expecting a Company Representative into Theatre must inform the theatre manager, specialty manager or deputy of that specialty in their absence.
6.4.3 Representatives must wear identification badges. The theatre Coordinator may refuse entry to representatives without MIA badges.
6.4.4 Whilst present in the Operating Theatres, suppliers and representatives will conduct themselves in an appropriate and professional manner.
6.4.5 Medical Device Representatives may act only as a resource regarding the representative's product, and may not scrub or actively participate in patient care.
6.4.6 When on site, all visitors must comply with any instructions given to them by an authorised member of staff in the event of an emergency situation arising e.g. fire.
6.4.7 All visitors must read the fire notice on arrival, paying particular attention to fire exits and break glass points.
6.4.8 When onsite, all representatives will be expected to comply with all hospital policies.

6.4.9 Commercial representatives must note that the Trust has an incident reporting policy. Should anyone be affected (patient, staff, student, visitor, volunteer or contractor by any behavioural actions from a commercial representative, the affected person should complete an incident report form.
Security of persons

6.5.1  There are circumstances when patients have to be accompanied by an officer; for example, police or prison officers. The attendance of these officers must be facilitated into the care of the patient.
Media filming/photography

6.6.1 Permission for journalists, film crews or photographers to visit theatres must be arranged in advance. These arrangements will only be made through the Trust's Press Office in discussion with the Operations Manager or Director of Operations.

6.6.2 If permission is given for a visit to take place, the department will identify a named contact to whom the press officer responsible for the visitors will report. This individual will ensure that visitors are properly briefed on arrival in the department.
6.6.3 All visits will begin at the theatre reception, even if filming or photography is to take place elsewhere.
6.6.4 The patient must be informed and consent sought before any filming or recording goes ahead.
Work observation students
6.7.1 No person under the age of  years is permitted access as a work/observation student within the operating theatres.

6.7.2 The Trust has a duty of care under The Health and Safety (Young Persons) Regulations (Health and Safety Executive, 1997) and Regulation 3 of the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations (Health and Safety Executive, 1992) to assess all risks to young people before they start work and introduce control measures, or minimise the risks so far as is reasonably practicable.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.
Monitoring compliance
Each document must outline the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.
As a minimum all procedural documents must include the process for review/monitoring of all the related requirements.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the TandA Clinical Governance committee, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local documents. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE theatre leads of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary equality analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
